results.justification: The paper explicitly states the research methodology, focusing on Grounded Prompt Engineering (GROPROE) for analyzing student reflections. (Section 2.3)
A flowchart (Figure 1) and detailed descriptions in Section 3 provide a step-by-step description of the study design, from codebook development to LLM analysis and evaluation.
The raw datasets are not publicly available. The paper mentions the data was collected as part of a wider research project at UTS.
The paper states the data collection was part of a study with ethics approval (ETH23-7776), implying privacy concerns are a justification for not sharing the raw data.

The paper describes the data collection process and provides details about the student reflections (length, stages). A detailed mapping from literature to code tree is available via a link (https://osf.io/qpe42/).
Data collection methods are fully described, including the use of student reflections collected at the start and end of a semester (Section 3.2).
The analysis code is not shared in an open repository.
There is no explicit justification provided for why the code is not shared.
Code for data preparation is not shared or mentioned.
The analysis is primarily qualitative, focusing on deductive coding and thematic analysis. Statistical tests are not a primary component.
Effect sizes, confidence intervals, and p-values are not reported as the study is primarily qualitative.
Subjective context and interpretation are given throughout the paper, particularly in the discussion of the LLM's reasoning and the evolution of the prompt (Section 5).
Data coding and analysis are clearly described, including the development of the codebook, the iterative refinement of the prompt, and the evaluation of coding consistency (Sections 3 and 4).
The results are clearly presented, including the IAR between human and LLM coding, and the LLMq results (Section 4).
Limitations and potential biases are discussed in Section 5.4, including the limited sample size for evaluation and the potential for chatbot sycophancy.
The paper does not contain a link to a preregistration.
